reviewText:
Quake 4 is yet another linear old-school'ish FPS in a Quake franchise. A franchise where no previous games were connected to each other, think of Final Fantasy. Quake 4 is proud exclusion, being a direct sequel to Quake 2, where space marines battle against cyborgs made of steel and human flesh on their planet. It was developed by Raven Software in 2005. And uses Doom 3 engine, so beware of sharp dynamic shadows.
There also was Collector Edition which came with Quake 2. As you expect, Steam version is not one. And there also was X360 port, that had Quake 2, some achievements and a bad optimisation. Not missing much there.

So, as for technical side. You will notice that textures are low quality even on Ultra Setting. That's because engine doesn't recognise mordern hardware for what it is and thinks you have very little memory and refuses to put correct settings in. You have to edit config files for textures. I recommend you to take a look at Steam community guides, there is a good one that tells you what commands to change.
I also would still have some small glitches with lights/shadows after playing for a while, but very minor and rarely, unlike what I had in Doom 3.
Another thing is that it had an awful lot of stuttering, especially when opening door to a new room. As if it tries to load something but for some reason has a lot of problems.
While game has options for widescreen aspect ratios, not all widescreen resolutions are there. Edit config for those too.
No alt-tab in fullscreen and no Steam Overlay.

As for multiplayer community, it's tiny. There are only few people, I only got to play in 3-player deathmatch. But in all honesty, since Multiplayer is similar to Quake 3 Arena one, it can be quite enough. You know, game where people tend to duel.
Apparently a lot of servers use Q4Max mod. It's low size anyway, and only seems to add more server options for competetive scenes, like full-bright skins, while not changing core gameplay itself, so it's OK. And some fixes. And gamemodes.

And in this plot you play as Kane, a silent protagonist and a badass who already got famous for things we don't get to do in this game. You are part of Rhino squad with who you will spend some of game time too, occasionally.

The Earth launched a second invansion on Strogg planet, hoping to fully clean it up while they are in supposed chaos as the certain badass killed their leader in Quake 2 (and another badass destroyed base on asteroid and another sissy blew up Gravity Well). Sure thing it was about as effective as assassination of political leaders, especially when we are talking about polished army of machines with purpose to kill, so you are about to get some more of hot time.
But at least this time 99% of marines weren't immeditly killed.
Not to mentioned that this time you will have some small cutscenes, radio chatters and NPCs to give the world more of living feel and to move a storyline. While still mostly focused on action and gameplay.

And yes, while it's not mazes, rather being what you would call a corridor shooter, it still can be considered old-school action. While having badass graphics. Frankly it didn't try to be spooky or dark like Doom 3, instead deliviring some shooting and aciton that Doom 3 didn't. And if you measure quality of FPS by how effective shotgun feels, then buy it immeditly, because shotgun in this makes ragdolls hoversault and just blows.

And yea, it's continuation of Quake 2, so you will see some familar elements from that game. But I feel that this one realized them much better. Which wasn't hard, seeing how Quake 2 felt unimpressive and somewhat generic even for a year of it's release. I mean, what tech advantages of Q2 would matter if you can't see anything past color red of art style. Anyway, Quake 4 isn't red, it actually has a art style that can show you dark grotesque images of creepy meat factories while staying colorful. Everything was slightly redesigned to be more badass too.

Gameplay also can be counted as superior. This one seems to pull weapons from Quake 3 arsenal though, with lighting gun and such. Well, with blaster instead of gaunlet. Don't worry, they are balanced around each other for single-player, having need to reload and special abilities of some. Monsters aren't as lame either. Melee berserkers can actually chase you down instead of never being able to hit a walking player. Monsters aren't as hitscan based either, having plenty projectiles to shoot and tactics to employ, making it more varied and fun too.

It's just shame that I can't say that it's music is better than Quake 2 soundtrack. I mean, main menu theme is nice and such and very Quake-like. But during actual gameplay you will be only occasionally hearing some kind of orchestra of sorts. Something from generic non-interesting heroic movies soundtracks. It still pumps you up during game, so it works.

And most awesomely, Raven Software took a few lessons from then-modern games and used them to improve pacing, variety and overall enjoyment of this linear campaign.

That includes masterful mix of rest moments and high-action ones. Sometimes you shoot many baddies, other times you are crawling over conveyer belts. To that extend it also employes parts where you are stuck on a turret of venichle or have to actually control one and get to another point. Thankfully, those sections are simple to control, aren't hard, short and fill quota on explosions, so they are most welcome.

Another thing that it takes are teammates. No longer you have to travel in Strogg world all alone, while failing to get immersed because you don't belive that every marine would become insane just from managing to land onto planet. I am referencing to Quake 2 again, yep. Sometimes in some sections of a game you will be followed by one or even up to three of marines, who will help you to effectively clear out the rooms, while rarely getting under your crosshair. They also don't suck, don't die easily and can kill stuff. And just make it feel more alive and that you are part of team. And some can heal and give armor. Don't worry, there is enough of lone wolf action, like one-man-army you are.

It also keeps on changing in player abilities, and not only by giving you weapons. It even updates the existing ones, giving them new propereties. Like turning nailgun (yes!) into scary weapon with projectiles that follow target. Or giving lighting gun ability to spread on others nearby. Thus also making you thing of how to balance your weapon choice and usage through the game. Even if railgun and lighting gun feel underwhelming.
It also even once updates your character, diving game into slower-paced half and into more of solo faster-paced one. Well, I am mostly talking of character speed. Let's not spoil the cutscene.

And yes, it has a few bosses. Not many, most are put together in the end of a game. But still some and they are nice, even if final boss feels a bit dissapointing. Maybe. Those are actually quite good last encounters, just can't help the feeling. I also should mention that last levels were actually surprisingly hard, died a few times.

Now, multiplayer part. It's Quake 3 copy! Why I never heard much of cheers and why didn't it replace Quake 3?

Well, not sure, some people mention something about netcode or about doesn't feel as good for some reason" or such. Though the more reasons that I can understand is that levels use single-player textures and assets in more dull way

reviewText:
This game is absolutely amazing. I remember once trying it out when I was younger and I never really made it very far into the game. But then my friend gave me this as a gift because like me he likes Quake and I thought 'well why not lets give it a go' and that was one of the greatest decisions of my life. the singleplayer campaign gave me around 8 hours of gameplay and it was spectacular.

the game has fantastic atmosphere and goes from badass shooter to tactical shooter to ♥♥♥♥ scary 'oh sweet jesus may god have mercy on my soul' in a matter of minutes. the game is fairly difficult to be honest, enemies do quite a bit of damage even on Corporal, which I assume is the 'normal' difficulty but it's never too hard only requiring you take your time and don't rush in guns blazing hoping things die. The guns are absolutely lovely and each enemy seems to have a gun that works best to kill them, some flat out requiring you smash them with the local superweapon which may at first sound like a pain in the ♥♥♥ but it really isn't, it's just the simplest way to take them down without using all of your ammo and I never found myself using the superweapon that often until the final level where I used the aforementioned 'rush in guns blazing and hope people die' strategy and it seemed to be the best way to go with little cover and all the strongest enemies trying to absolutely destroy you. One 'issue' I had though is that there never seemed to be more than a few enemies attacking you at any given time, wether this was an issue with ID tech 4 (the game engine) or wether this was just a design choice made by the developers to help with the fact that enemies do quite a lot of damage and you need to sit back and take your time and if you didn't constantly fire and risk getting shot right in the face then you would quickly be overrun.

all in all the dark setting, kickass weaponry and all round 'creepy' atmosphere (which makes sense, this is war time and your forces seem to be very heavily outnumbered by the Strogg) really work well to keep you very interested in the game and I never fealt myself getting bored and wanting to play something else. The story is pretty interesting (or I thought so atleast) and the characters aren't all that bad themselves though they do come off as ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s most of the time by making you walk off on your own to fend for yourself in this horrific setting with monsters potentially around every corner wanting to rip your face off but it made getting back to them so that you aren't dealing with the horrors alone all the more relieving and you never really go too long without someone there to watch your back which some may see as an annoyance that takes away from the dark and scary atmosphere but I don't really like that all too much and I'd much rather have that in bursts and still have someone there to keep me company so I don't go completely insane from time to time.

so all things considered this is a truely great game and I would more than recommend you buy this, I would recommend you get some friends to as well (I found a co op mod and haven't tested it myself but have high hopes). the game is fun, story is enjoyable and I found myself connecting with the character and found myself putting myself in their shoes which is a great thing for games to do and I don't get often. though I do wish that I could have more than two weapons with torches on them while it does add to the creepiness as they are the two weakest weapons in the game (well the lightning gun is pretty bad but atleast it looks cool).

Gameplay - 10/10
Story - 9/10
Badassery - 11/10 (gun that basically shoots black holes!)

Overall - 10/10

Oh and don't even bother with the multiplayer, I do like that it is VERY heavily based on Quake 3 and if you liked Quake 3 as much as me you will probably like the little bit of nostalgia offered by it but that's about it.

reviewText:
Semi-Nostalgia distant planet fps, that turned out to be quite decent, Quake 4 brings you a terrific game with graphics from the early 2000s, and gameplay at it's finest. You are Corporal Kane, and here brings you this mission: drive the strogg, your enemy, back to hell!

I first got this game in 2006 (not on steam), after my dad showed me the quake series with him. I thought the game was truly one of the top-dogs back then, the storyline was actually very well detailed, combat seemed smooth, and difficulty seemed well played (despite that those spider enemies make me want to kill myself half the time). The weaponry you are given seems very well flexible, the machinegun wasn't very useless, the shotgun didn't seem useless, and balancing your ammo with every gun seems very thorough. Quake 4 also has multiplayer (but noone really plays that anymore).

The few boss encounters in this game seemed very difficult at first, but after a while, it isn't really that bad, considering a few  enemies late in the game have the same complexity as one or two bosses. The ways to kill every boss seemed interesting (noticing every boss in the game has a health bar, so I think there is 3 or 4? There may be more, but those are enemies you'll never see a lot as you walk around on the battlefield) and the final boss was the most interesting, along with the story that went with it.

Yet, I could see a little improvement, since I'm told there might be a new Quake (there is a new Doom coming out), I did see some slight errors with the game. The game's AI that are on your side seem to be a little wonky at times, sometimes they'll be overpowered, sometimes they won't. The enemy AI rarely screws up, and when it does, you'll sometimes need to literally restart a checkpoint, which could get frustrating. All-in-all, I didn't see that many glitches/bugs/exploits in the game.

The level design for almost every level seem very organized, balanced, and smooth. Early in the game they don't throw that many obstacles in your path, but later in the game, they'll toss in a hefty amount of enemies, spiced up to hardcoreness. As I mentioned difficulty earlier, there are four difficulties to the game (pretty simplistic, right?), Private for the easiest level, and General for the hardest. I've only played on the mid-tier difficulties, Corporal and Lieutenent (Normal/Hard). Both of the mid-tier seem very easy to play after you've had a chance to deal with every enemy. Fighting each boss on the easier difficulties, you'll know what to do on harder difficulties (bla bla bla).

Is this worth the price tag? If you really want to wait for a sale, I'd wait for a seasonal sale, or quakecon sale. It's definitly worth the twenty dollars if you're looking for a decent challenge, and a game that's somewhat old, but actually feels smooth.

Doom 3 is essentially a remake of the original Doom, though series fans will find reimagined versions of almost every monster from both Doom and Doom II in the new sequel. You play as a nameless, voiceless 22nd-century space marine called by the Union Aerospace Corporation to its Mars research facility beset with mysterious problems--the forces of hell, to be exact. You'll end up single-handedly fighting back legions of hellspawn using weapons like shotguns, machine guns, and rocket launchers. As in the classic Doom games, your foes here are liable to strike at any time--often just as you round a corner, grab a much-needed power-up, or set foot into a new area. So, while your enemies will materialize without notice, and may occasionally startle you as they leap out of the darkness, Doom 3 cannot easily be described as scary or suspenseful, but is still an amazing experience at first hand.

With the Quakecon sale kicking off on Friday, I was a bit surprised to see that there was a Quake 4!  Sure, I got away from PC gaming for awhile and it had been a REALLY long time since I was heavy into Doom and Quake, but I felt a little funny that I didn't know this existed!  With a cheap price I figured it was a must play for nostalgia's sake at the very least. I didn't expect a whole lot out of it, which is good because it turns it's okay.  Not great, but okay.

I run a couple of movie podcasts, so I watch a lot of flicks.  The state of the modern shooter in comparison to classic style shooters compares pretty well to the world of movies.  Most of the time, you like to watch a movie that's well put together, highly polished, engaging and engrossing.  This translates to your modern shooters in the game world.  Games such as Bioshock Infinite or even Deadspace are a different beast than the shooters we all cut our teeth on.  They're deep, they have branching stories, they're well put together. It's a production...an experience.

Jumping back to your movie world. you have another class of movie which boils down to your dumb action or horror movies, stuff put out by the likes of Syfy Channel or Asylum.  These movies are cheesy with no depth whatsoever.  They're there simply to treat you to explosions and special effects, nothing more than the spectacle.  Quake 4 fits in perfectly with this type of movie; there' s no depth to it whatsoever, it's there simply for you to run around and shoot aliens.  And that's it.

Much like watching the movies though, sometimes we simply don't feel like wrapping our head around something deep. We want to munch popcorn and watch stuff explode.  Video games are the same way, and Quake 4 is a pretty perfect fit for those moods.  It's a solid through back to the good old days where you're only concern was checkpoints and finding your way to the rail gun.  The story is a nice aside but really doesn't do anything to suck you into the game.  You're sticking around for the fun of shooting Stroggs and seeing what the weapons do.

There's some sections in Quake 4 that are annoying.  The vehicle sections are slow and clunky which makes them frustrating when you're trying to dodge.  Some of them feel like you're on a rail shooter without a whole lot to shoot at.  The game is way too long for what you're there for too.

In the end though, things blow up pretty well and it play smoothly while showing it's age.  It's worth $5 and a Sunday afternoon.

reviewText: Quake 4 is fun. The story is shady, though. It's essentially Iraq/Afghanistan War propaganda. The story is that you're part of the marines invading a desert planet fighting the locals, much like what the US was doing when this game was released. The graphics still hold up fairly well considering this game is just about a decade old. There are a lot of well realized technologically, industrially advanced locations filled to the brim with details. The setting is gritty sci-fi and the aesthetics really sold the dark atmosphere. There is a fair amount of gore in the game. The game certainly has some similarities to Doom 3, which was released around the same time. Quake 4 leans more towards sci-fi where Doom 3 more towards super natural horror. The lighting is really well done. The colorful lights from the computer screens and machines contrast well with the mostly otherwise pitch dark rooms. Think of the lighting at a rave and you've got it. When first arriving on the planet, the main character can't understand the alien writing on computers and it just looks like jibberish, but a little ways in something happens to him and then the computer consoles start displaying messages in English, like the character learned to understand the language. The main character looks like Robocop without his visor on and it looks bizarre. The combat is decent. There are a lot of corridor battles and the 'ol trusty running backwards in a circle, shooting up the enemy tactic still works a bit too well. The weapons were standard issue. There wasn't anything too exciting, but they were suitable for the game were fun to shoot. The level design is mostly simple and straight forward, but combat was never boring. The boss battles were challenging, yet not too bad. I will say, the final boss was much more difficult than I anticipated. It took me a while to figure exactly what I needed to do. There are some on rails sections and some where vehicles are controlled that break up the on foot parts that make up a bulk of the game. Frequently NPC marines will join the fight and every one of them gets a name and so I always felt bad when they'd inevitably get mowed down. It took around 10 hours to finish. Quake 4 is not the revolution that the first one was two decades ago, but it is still a fun game that holds up today.

reviewText:
I am writing this review after getting frustrated with the game on the easiest difficulty and giving up. Read on to find out why.

For reference, I am playing on the PC version with a trackball. Even then, the mouse sensitivity on the highest setting is still woefully slow for the majority of combat situations you will be finding yourself in during the course of this game. I hope your mousing hand has had training from Usain Bolt, because you'll need every ounce of arm speed you can muster.

What on earth is a reload mechanic doing in a Quake game? Considering the Quake games (used to) focus more on mobility and feeling like a badass even when the odds were not in your favour, having to hide and reload (or worse, having to reload in the middle of a heated firefight) really destroys the pacing of the combat. The mechanic itself is not a bad one, but it is handled poorly in this game. You get the sense that it wasn't planned into the fabric of the game very well at all. It is infuriatingly slow to reload and a lot of the time, as stated before, you find yourself in the middle of a fierce battle having to reload. Now, often this isn't a problem when you are with other members of your squad, but if you are in a solo battle, you have very little chance to survive. Indeed, I find that if the PC game did not have a quick save/load feature, this game would not be recommendable in the slightest. (I wouldn't dare try playing this game on a console under any circumstances.) The only way you can have a hope of surviving (and even then, it is a slim chance) is by mashing the reload key/button after every battle, no matter how big or small, because if you don't have full clips for all weapons before you turn the next corner, you will be toast, more often than not. I have found that the way to get around the slow reloads is to make sure you have a full reload in all weapons and simply switching weapons instead, because switching weapons is much faster than reloading.

Speaking about slow, your run speed in this game is slower than Quake 1's walk speed! Trying to run away from enemies is useless. Just pump ammo into them until you run out, then give up, die and restart. You will have to play through the previous 10 minutes of gameplay again.

Also, this game is entirely too hard. As stated in the intro, I was playing on the Private difficulty level, which is the easiest of the four difficulty levels, and I cannot count the number of times I have found myself surrounded by enemies with an empty clip in my gun or less than 20 health. I had to quick load some parts of this game up to 20 times just to try and see if I could quickly kill a guy behind me (whom I couldn't hear because of radio chatter from my squad) while I was on under 10 health. This is immensely frustrating, and is essentially the reason why I could not be bothered to finish the game. If I am having such difficulty with the easiest setting, what use is there playing a harder difficulty?

There are some really good aspects to this game though. The atmosphere of war at the beginning of the game, and being able to work with your squad in the more typical war-battle based segments was great. It really captured the sense of battling an enemy much more powerful than you, but still giving you the feeling that you had a chance against them. (That feeling didn't last longer than 30 minutes, though. You get quickly overpowered by the enemies.) Your squad also help you when you have to hide and reload. (When you are allowed to fight with them, of course.)

Multiplayer is basically a copy of Quake 3. Owing to my single player experience in this game, I didn't try multiplayer, because I have Quake 3 and would rather play that instead. Quake 3 is even a better single-player game anyway, even with its lack of a story or campaign.

In summary, Quake 4 is to Quake what Doom 3 was to Doom. It could have been a decent game… only if it was thought through much better, and wasn't called Quake. Associating this game with Quake's rich heritage and therefore, having fans of the series remember and try to apply the play style and tactics of the earlier Quake games, has done more harm than good to this game.

If you like sci-fi war FPS games and have no knowledge of the Quake series, this might be an enjoyable experience for you. Pick it up for £5 or less if you want to give it a go. It isn't worth more than that in my opinion. However, if you have any experience of the previous Quake games (and I have been playing Quake since it came out in the late 90s), I would steer clear of this game. Despite the title, it's not Quake.

Where Doom 3 was interesting, New and felt cool...Quake 4 failed to keep what made quake interesting.

I bought the game when it was on sale back during the Quakecon promotion (mostly for the Genuine Original Rocket Launcher for TF2) and if you buy this for more than $30, you will feel cheated.

5 hours is all it took me to beat the game's story, and I wasn't trying hard.

Just get Quake 1 or 2...Mostly 2

reviewText:
Not a bad game but I can't recommend buying it when the price is 20 euros. I've had a great time playing this shooter but only after installing some mods. Let me put this straight - this game is not properly optimised for Steam. I have a good graphics and enough RAM to run most games but this Quake 4 game even when put in Ultra Quality settings has crappy textures. Add an overall gray-brown-black-metal surrounding and your graphics may look like well, mud.

I have most of the same gripes with this game as I've had with Serious Sam 2 - the vanilla game didn't age well. Graphics are not optimised for High Definition, the main character is moving pretty slow for a cyborg, some encounters seems heavily scripted, weapons sometimes don't pack as much punch as they should.

But after installing SIKK MOD and PARALAX MOD the game just got better. Graphics are finally nice - dynamic lights, most of objects are retextured to some HD textures, we get some blur effects, etc.. But we also get some problems with levels loading and game crashing after modding so this is a mixed bag of goodies and uglies.

Let's try to sum up all of pros and cons for Quake 4

Pros:
- modded graphics look really pretty
- enemies are grotesque, mechanical monsters with solid design
- sound is fine
- plot is ok for a single player mode
- weapons have nice design - Nailgun and BFG both look nice and have a considerable power
- sometimes we can control vehicle like tank or mech suit

Cons:
- although vehicles are fun, those levels with vehicles are pretty long and boring
- some of weapons are underpowered - I think that grenade launcher, rocket launcher and most of all railgun are somewhat weak
- graphics without mods
- most weapons have clips that you need to reload every now and then - really, who thought that would be a good idea in a Quake game? For example Railgun has a 3 ammo in a clip. Most stronger enemies take 3-5 hits with a railgun. Same goes for shotgun - we need to reload it slug after slug up to the point where we get a magazine upgrade and then we can reload a whole magazine (about half of the game). Luckily, we can remove clips with a SIKK mod
- character moves really slow and enemies move fast. That can escalate rather quick... - we can change that with SIKK mod
- no replay value - single player campaign is scripted and multiplayer is possibly dead
- buggy as hell when modded - I needed to move config files manually every now and then when some levels didn't load. It was pretty annoying to save game just before next loading screen, then exit to desktop, move files, run game, load saved game, pass through a loading screen into a next level, save game, exit to desktop, move back those files, run game, load saved game and finally play it. Really, this is pain when you need to do this about 20 times during whole game.

After all I can recommend playing this game after modding it a bit (if you can grab it for let's say 5 bucks/euros that is) but if you're not a Quake fan then you can skip it. It's definitely not worth 20 euros, it aged poorly and looks bad without mods. I've had fun but I would not play this game a second time. It's barely playable without mods and thus I can't give thumbs up to a game that requires mods to be fun.

reviewText:
The alternate to DOOM, only in this game, they were able to afford more electricians to keep most of the lights still working.

It's time for another Quake, not another DOOM.

Good gfx, sound, weapons, level design is ok. Setting is nice (and like I mentioned earlier, a lot more of the lights are working compared to DOOM!!!) You get to use mechs and tanks; for me, these are the more difficult parts for me (I'm more for traditional fps, not vehicle combat). Some levels can be difficult at times, you get to a save point or have to quick save to save yourself from having to replay a longer section of the game over again, but now maybe your stuck with less ammo and health to take on a challenge. In these situations, you just have to play that challenge slowly and methodically, practice, make your shots counts (memorize the AI behaviors, anticipate them). Unless you've royally screwed yourself, then you may need to restart.

If you liked DOOM, you'll like this. It's basically a lighter (literally) sci-fi alternative to DOOM. DOOM was dark and demonic and it worked well for that. This is more fighting disgusting aliens (& becoming one, an ugly duckling for sure) in a slightly more military themed environment, still heavy on sci-fi, though, and I like that. No health regen, just health paks. No ADS/iron sights (can we have another quake that has this, please?). This is more of a run (dogde vs. cover) and gun like the traditional/older FPS games.

The Game as i said is quite fun, a nice variety of guns all effective and fairly fun to use, enemies to use them on, and a few surpsrisingly fun vehicle sections - except that first turret section jesus christ. the game feels like the baby of Doom 3 with its enviroments, graphics and gameplay and Call of Duty due to the strong presence of your NPC space marine companions.  The game feels railroady a bit early on and the NPC's stole all most of the kills  but you lose them at certain and thankfully lengthy sections later and the action picks up considerably. The story picks up all the missed opurtunities Quake 2 dropped and it feels a lot more interesting because of it, certain sections even gave me chills with how well done they were. All in all i give it a recomendation.
